How It Works: Consumer defines contract (subset of provider API it uses). Provider verifies it satisfies all consumer contracts. Shared broker tracks compatibility.
Detection Method: Contract verification; broker management; compat matrix
AI Improvement: Generate initial contracts by analyzing consumer code for actual provider endpoint/field usage
Strengths: Tests only what consumer needs; enables independent deploy; contracts are living coupling documentation
Limitations: Requires discipline to maintain; initial broker setup cost; versioning complex with many consumers

How It Works: Both sides independently generate API descriptions (consumer from mocks; provider from running API). Broker compares for compatibility.
AI Improvement: Explain semantic differences beyond schema shape — 'same name; different meaning'
Strengths: Low adoption friction; teams keep existing mocking tools; fast to start
Limitations: Less precise than CDC; can miss semantic mismatches; requires both sides to keep specs accurate

How It Works: Single source of truth schema (protobuf; Avro; GraphQL SDL). Both sides compile against it. CI enforces backward compatibility.
Tools: protobuf + buf; Avro + Schema Registry; GraphQL registry
Detection Method: buf; Avro compat modes; protobuf checks — formal verification
Strengths: Strongest shape guarantees; breaking changes caught at compile time; single source of truth
Limitations: Only validates shape; not behavior; requires all teams on same IDL; doesn't catch logic bugs

How It Works: Provider publishes API contract (OpenAPI; AsyncAPI). Consumer validates usage against published spec.
Detection Method: Spec linting; schema validation; consumer test execution
AI Improvement: Review provider specs against your actual usage to identify which changes matter to you
Strengths: Works without provider running your tests; fast feedback against real spec
Limitations: Provider may change spec without warning; trusting spec accuracy; one-directional

How It Works: Record real API interactions from staging. Store as snapshots. Replay in CI to detect changes. Alert on divergence from baseline.
AI Improvement: Flag semantic changes (same shape; different meaning) that schema comparison misses; identify stale snapshots
Strengths: Captures actual behavior; not just docs; works without provider cooperation
Limitations: Snapshots go stale; staging may not match prod; brittle with dynamic content

How It Works: Negotiate lightweight SLA (response time; error rates; uptime). Run integration tests in shared environment validating SLA.
Detection Method: SLA monitoring; synthetic transactions; breach alerting
AI Improvement: Draft SLA proposals by analyzing actual service behavior and usage patterns; review SLAs for ambiguity
Strengths: Formalizes relationship; SLA breaches create shared accountability; catches performance issues
Limitations: Integration tests are slower/flakier; shared environments are fragile; only detects after deployment

How It Works: Write tests defining exact subset of third-party API you depend on. Run against mocks in CI. Periodically verify against real API.
Tools: Pact consumer-only; Specmatic; JSON Schema validation
Detection Method: Running tests against mocks and scheduling real-API checks
AI Improvement: Generate expectations by analyzing codebase for every third-party API call and response dependency
Strengths: You own the definition; catches drift pre-production; mocks keep CI fast
Limitations: Your expectations may be wrong; lag before detecting changes; real-API runs can be rate-limited

How It Works: Continuously run synthetic transactions against live third-party API. Monitor response shape; latency; error rates. Alert on deviation.
Tools: Checkly; Datadog Synthetics; Grafana; CloudWatch Synthetics
Detection Method: Synthetic monitoring — purpose-built tools for reliability and consistency
Strengths: Near-real-time detection; low setup for critical paths; monitors availability + correctness
Limitations: Only tests defined paths; rate limits; doesn't catch changes pre-deploy; smoke-test depth

How It Works: Wrap third-party API in adapter translating their model to your domain. Test adapter extensively. External changes only require adapter updates.
Detection Method: Adapter unit tests; simulated API tests; CI execution
AI Improvement: Help design adapter by analyzing third-party API surface and your domain model for translation mapping
Strengths: Insulates codebase; change surface is one adapter; enables provider substitution; clean domain model
Limitations: Higher upfront cost; adapter can have bugs; still need canary for external change detection

How It Works: Monitor vendor changelog; status page; dev communications. Auto-trigger regression suite on detected changes.
Tools: RSS/webhook monitoring; GitHub Actions; regression suite
Detection Method: Triggering regression suites from webhooks — automation/CI
AI Improvement: Parse vendor changelogs and release notes to assess impact on your integration — strong NLU use case
Strengths: Proactive; combines vendor comms with verification; builds knowledge of vendor patterns
Limitations: Vendors don't always announce changes; changelog parsing brittle; high maintenance
